A hokum doctor, ay. Always doing things you know, with the animals, es’periments and what have you-
And what again was the exact amount of money you said was missing?
Two hundred twenty quid.
Aha, would that be your whole London take?
It would- The door opens and ALISTAIR Oberon, 36, with an immaculat kept mustache, leans in.
Inspector Turpin, a word outside? EXT. BARNABY’S TRAILER —- CONTINUOUS It’s nearing dawn. Alistair and Turpin pow-wow, Turpin closing the door in Barnaby’s face.
Well, he’s lying about the money.
How do you figure?

When would the hunchback have taken it? The footprints from the cage only go one way, the hunchback and its accomplice had no agenda here in the circus; they wanted to get to the city. Mister Barnaby’s just trying to swindle the insurance.

Indeed. What I came to tell you was, they’ve gotten the body cleaned up off the boat, and we've got conflicted reports. Two of the tumblers are saying the hunchback threw him off the bridge, two are saying he jumped by himself.
Oh he threw him, most definitely. The differences in story can be explained by delusion, heat of the moment. (MORE)
There’s something rather strange about all this though, don’t you think? Sinister.
How do you figure?

The cage shows no signs of tampering, yet the lock had opened. The wound to the face of the Manager came from a claw, the injury to the strongman shows a super-human strength, not to mention there’s talk of the hunchback doing “science” as its primary pastime...You don’t find it somewhat ghoulish?
(beat, awkwardly) Inspector, I’ve been meaning to say...I, that is to say, all of us at the Yard- what happened with Claudia is a tragedy, sir.
...Beg pardon-
Your wife, Claudia; her passing was-
I’m sorry, what relevance does Claudia have to this?
Well, none but-
Claudia is in Heaven. Our separation is merely temporary. What is your implication about my state of mind?
I didn’t mean-
Didn't you? Turpin smiles, seeming to realize how he was coming off.
I have my daughter, my home, my job. This too shall pass, Constable.
Yes sir. Of course sir.  28.

(back to business) There was an accident with a high wire girl last night. The hunchback was involved, as I understand it. Have our men question everyone in this place, see if we can find out which hospital she was taken to.
Yes sir.
Have the artist Walsh make up pictures, and then have prints made: one hundred of the Hunchback, fifty of his accomplice, and then have them posted everywhere from Westminister to Bethnal Green.
Yes sir.
There is a murderous hunchback loose in London. This will not stand.
Igor curled up in his bed, morning light flooding in thro the windows. He stirs.

(quietly) Chisick Cross.
Igor sits at a table consulting a big map of London; we c tell by the way he mumbles to himself, his eyes darting a over, that he’s absorbing the data, easily and quickly committing it to memory.

Igor steps out, but the hustle and bustle of the busy str in daytime scares the shit out of him, and he jumps back inside. A moment later he reemerges.  29. We follow Igor as he walks up the street, in awe at every and everything.
Igor investigates every fruit, every meat, every spice. H having the time of his life. To entertain a few children, juggles some apples. They’re wowed.
Igor walks up the street, bag of groceries under his arm. has a slightly more confident gait, now; he knows where h going and why.

The hospital is dank and dirty, really just one large warehouse style room filled with the sick and dying. Igor cautiously heads in, nervous, looking remarkably clean cu and pristine amongst all the filth. He starts to walk in, when he’s called out by a gruff mal nurse, dirty and frightening.

I- oh, I’m sorry, I’ll- I’1l go-

I- No, I’m just looking for a friend. She was an aerialist, at the circus.

Friend. Hah. End of the line, behind the curtains. Igor smiles cautiously, still scared of the nurse, and th hurries down the row of beds, getting more and more excit as he approaches the curtained off area at the end- -The curtains pull back, revealing Lorelei, nearly unconscious in her sickbed-
Lorelei-  30. -Inspector Turpin and Constable Alistair. Igor freezes, confused.

I just- I just-

I- yes- no- I-

I- No, I'm- just a friend- Turpin looks to Lorelei, who clearly is in no shape to an questions, much less recognize Igor. Turpin takes a step forward, backing Igor out of the curtained area.

I- what’re you- Turpin has drawn out an artist’s depiction of Victor, and consulting it against Igor’s features.
Interesting. This girl is being questioned in connection with the rampage of the Blue Meringue Hunchback last night on the Thames.
(horrified) The- the what-

I didn’t- Ig- I’m Igor-
Igor what.

What’s the hurry?
I have to go- I have to go- Igor turns, nearly walking into a patient, rushing frantically out of the hospital. Constable Alistair pokes his head out.
Strange lad. Probably went to the circus and found himself love- struck, is what I take it. Hunted her down looking to be a benefactor, happens all the time with women like this.

Maybe. Maybe. “Igor.” Hm. OUTSIDE... Igor comes crashing out into the street, running blindly, panicked. He tries to orient himself, and comes face to f with one of the WANTED: HUNCHBACK posters. Victor walks up the street, mumbling angrily. He stops in front of his door, composes himself, and then goes in.

Igor, I’m- Victor stops dead. There’s a trail of mud on the floor, which he follows to find Igor sitting in his muddy clothe the fire, hunched over in a caveman-like squat unbecoming his new appearance.
Back to the mud so soon? Igor looks up at him, eyes wide.
I take it you've seen the posters then. Terrible depiction of me, have my hair all wrong. I’m new to this “criminal” life, but I never suspected they’d attack my vanity.  32.
...They think I’m a murderer-
Well you’re not. And they’re not looking for you, are they? Igor’s confusion is obvious.
They're looking for a piteous, nameless hunchback. A creature who no longer exists. I’ve seen to that, haven’t I? Igor hesitantly smiles; Victor has a way with words.
Dinner?
Victor and Igor are sharing a roast duck.

Of course I never put much faith in the professors. Father says most of them get their job through crony- ism as is; many of them I fear are drunks, idiots, or worse, close- minded people. I find I have a terrible fear of the close minded and ignorant as they seem to do the most damage to society as a whole.
(happy about the duck) Mhm.

Of course the curriculum is pathetically easy, laughably so; I could even laugh about it now, but to do so would expend more effort than I’m asked to expend of my studies, literally the act of saying “haha” would be more difficult than-
So you like school then?
...I suppose I do.
What brought you to the circus?  33.
(beat) The animals.
Oh, you like the animal tricks? They were always my favorite too-
Living animals are a bore. It’s the dead ones I was after.
Beg pardon?
For parts. (in response to Igor’s confusion) I believe an explanation is in order. My interest in you did not stem from charity. (beat) I think it’s time you met my monster.
Victor leads in Igor, turning on the lights. This room is cluttered, but more purposefully than the others; there’s table in the center with several larger objects on it, covered by a sheet.
Before I met you, I was hoping to approach Mr. Barnaby about selling me some of his deceased animals.
To what end? Study?
No. Not study. (beat) I am of the strong belief that death can be made a temporary condition.
But that’s im-
Improbable, yes, impossible, don’t be stupid. Very little is actually impossible. Life is temporary, why should death be any different?
...What’s under the sheet?  34.

...Life, I’ve found, is an energy. The fools would call it a spirit or a soul, but it’s an energy, an identifiable, quantifiable, reproducible energy. I’d spent every hour of my life in pursuit of this energy, and then, last year, a break through. I ama genius, and I created something that will change the world.

.-.-Righto. What’s under the sheet? Victor yanks away the sheet, revealing a small electrical generator...And a set of human eyes, a with an interlaced optical nervous system, suspended in fluid in a fish tank Ah-
ha.

The eyes are over three months old, and the fluid is electrically conductive jelly. Serves a double function to preserve them, and- well, look, here.... Igor, initially repulsed, goes up and gets a better look Victor searches through piles of equipment.
You've done a shoddy job on the nerves here-

Well, I’m not the surgeon, it’s you with the gifted hands- there! Victor draws inches long, over it. At wrought iron out a gizmo from the pile. It’s all a matter of conversion, you see; the conversion of pure electrical energy into biological energy, of the same sort that flows through the bodies of the living. Thus my creation of this device, the Lazarus Fork. You see, by running the electrical current through a specially blended variety of metal and sulfates, I’ve-  35.
You’ve mastered the conversion.
Well- I- yes.
Show me.

I- uh, yes, I shall- Victor plunges the Lazarus fork into the jelly, and begin turning the crank on the generator; it kicks in, and the electricity begins to flow with a loud rattle and hum. Igor leans down to the eyes. Victor, excited, goes around and stands next to him.
When does it do...something-

It has! It is! It- here, look! Victor draws out a match, and strikes it on the table. Th effect is immediate: the eyes turn and focus on the flame Victor moves it back and forth, and the eyes move to foll Victor looks to Igor, nervous.
You are a genius. You have created something that will change the world.
This is only the beginning.
Victor leads Igor out into an open area.
To what degree would you say you understand the function and construction of nerves in the human body?
Well I-
No tolerance for the humble here, Igor.
I have a complete mastery of the nervous and circulatory systems. (MORE)

I am also well versed in the form and structure of the muscles and bones. I also am quite up to date on the deductions made about the function the different parts of the brain serve, although I believe most of the current observations will, in time, prove to be completely wrong.

I- uh- good. Good! Perfect. This will be your workspace. I shall bring you your assignments piecemeal, and you will complete them in a timely manner. I will then apply your projects to a larger whole of my own design. I’ve also decided to allow you to do my homework assignments for me, thus enhancing your already formidable knowledge. Do you have any questions?
...-This larger whole. What is it?
That is not your concern-
But if my work will go towards it, surely I deserve to-
As I said. This was not charity. Your time here will be earned; what you “deserve” is immaterial, agreed?
(after a beat) ...-Agreed. I want to help change the world. Victor smiles, and extends his hand, which Igor tentative shakes.

Intercutting between two threads... 1. Turpin’s intensifying search for the Hunchback. The wanted posters are getting old and worn, new ones are bei plastered up, the reward for information doubling... And  37. 2. Igor’s work. We watch as time and time again Victor brings him moist newly dead flesh (much of it of unidentifiable nature), along with supplies and diagrams what he wants done. Igor masterfully stitches together sk and tissue, creates artificial nerves and veins with elec wiring and thin rubber tubes... It’s all very gross, but Igor, looking through goggles, magnifying glasses and microscopes, is so into it we can’ help but share his enthusiasm. After each assignment, Victor demonstrates his emphatic approval, before retreating to the basement with the “finished product” (lungs that breath, muscles that twitc nerves that react) each time slamming the door. SLAM SLAM SLAM SLAM...

Igor moves to set the I.STRAUSSMAN letter on a pile by th door of other mail for Victor’s absent roommate, but then falters. He hesitates, and listens for Victor; nothing. Igor opens the envelope, and scans through the letter ins PAYMENT 2 MONTHS OVERDUE. FINAL NOTICE. The door to the basement bursts open, startling Igor.
This letter for Master Straussman, it- Victor is positively glowing with happiness.
We’re going out on the town.
Victor and Igor head up the street, talking.
I have a tenured membership in the club through my father. He was a charter member, helped to buy the velvet for the seats.
You make your father out to be a great man.  38.
Esteemed doctor, member of the royal corps of physicians, he’s a innovator, he’s brilliant.
Do you think I’1l ever get to meet him?
Oh I don’t- I- I don’t know, he’s a very busy man, and he- his schedule, you know.
You mentioned he had a library?
The biggest personal collection of medical texts in Britain, yes, you could say he has a library-
Do you think he has a copy of Thompson’s?
Thompson’s Anatomy? Well, it’s rare but, I mean, of course-
Do you think we could go there, to his library?
What’s this fixation on Thompson's?
In the circus, I had a copy. It was a great inspiration to me.

Well, I- you know, he doesn’t let me- give me access, I’m just a young man- he’d be so angry if he found out I’d been touching his books- oh, look, here we are! They've come up on THE EXETER, an extremely fancy (and hi and fun, and crowded) looking club.
Oh...Master Victor, I don’t know if I’m suited for all this-  39.
Pishposh. All you need to do is keep your back straight, your words clean, and try your damndest not to embarrass me.

INT. THE EXETER —- CONTINUOUS Victor is WASTED, sitting in a corner booth with Igor and few girls. The club is awesome, and packed; the girls are pretty damn hot, too, but they’re mostly focused on Igor, himself is trying not to notice, instead focusing on Vict
(laughing) Victor why does this idea fascinate you?

I’m just saying the act- of FERTILIZATION- can take place out side of the woman’s body. The sperm, the sperm can move- (hiccup) The sperms can move into the egg, say, in a saucer, some sort of heated basin-
And where does the mother figure into this, then?
Well, you’d- after you impregnate the egg, you get a funnel- and then you...you know- into the woman-
Oh, that’s just wretched.

IT’S THE FUTURE! Igor, tell them, assist me in this, this valuable endeavor. Igor doesn’t respond; he’s staring across the club to the bar... ..-Where Lorelei stands. She looks stunning. Gone is all the muck and grime of the circus, though she still wears sling over her injured arm.

Igor catches up to Lorelei at the top of the stairs; she turns, sensing his presence before he can say anything. T stand there deadlocked in silence, staring at each other. She suddenly embraces him; Igor is shocked. She whispers into his ear, her words fraught with emotion.

You saved my life. You saved my life. Igor let's out a sigh of complete relief. LATER... Igor and Lorelei are hanging out, leaning on one of the balconies over the club; they’re completely relaxed, talk like old friends, or, more accurately, refugees.
Penham Mall? That’s really fancy, though, isn’t it?
Oh, you know, just the richest section of London. Haha, I’m sorry, I’m awful.
You can be awful when you look great, isn’t that the way people behave?
High praise from a bloke who’s twice the man he used to be, in height alone.
Well, I, uh- I don’t really- um- So does he intend to marry you?
Who, Baron Bomine? I think you misunderstand our relationship-
Do I?
Oh, and now I see a glint of hope in your eye.  4l.
Oh no, I just- um- listening-

I met him in the hospital; he was in with a twisted ankle of all things, and he just swept me away once he’d heard the circus left without me. At first he did come on awfully romantic, but- honestly I’ve come to believe that he’s taken me in as his consort more for appearances than anything else.
Appearances? Lorelei nods down at BARON BOMINE, who’s on the main floo He’s the gayest man alive.
Aaaah. Oh. IGOR (CONT’D) LORELEI Robert the Juggler. Robert the Juggler. Both of them immediately crack up.

I don’t know why you’re laughing. I think it’s very important for a juggler to have a sincere love of balls- Both of them crack up again, and then there’s a ruckus fr downstairs; Igor looks and sees that Victor’s accidentall knocked some plates on the floor whilst animatedly gestur
Isn’t that your chap there?
Yes, Victor Frankenstein. Smartest person I’ve ever met. He’s the one who helped me save you, as well. He got me out of the circus, fixed my back...I owe him everything.
Have you ever seen a human brain? It's...GRAY!
(faltering) He’s quite brilliant, really, just not so much of a...person for talking to people.

(audible over the crowd) I’ve seen a rat nest in a brain!  42. Igor looks to Lorelei, trying to hold back a laugh. She doesn’t do as well holding back. The ruckus downstairs continues; Victor’s pissed off some jerk.
Ah, it looks like he may need my-
But of course. Igor starts to go, but then stops.
Listen, we’re right in the West End, on Verner Street.
Forty Five Penham Lane.
So we’ll see each other again.
Yes. Definitely.
My name is Igor.

“Igor.”
Victor is puking into a pile of garbage, while Igor stand next to him, patting his back.
People are such animals, you know...I don’t understand them, I admit this, to some degree. I don’t know the things to say to make them like me, or- not like me, I don’t care if they like me-

What?
It’s all right to care if people like you. I like you.  43.
I...like you, as well. Yes. (beat, straightens up) Igor, tonight was not meaningless frivolity. It is a celebration.

The electric lights flicker and hum to life, illuminating most sinister, fascinating place you’ve ever seen. Come on, come on! Igor hesitates at the top of the stairs, then slowly come down. Victor, meanwhile, primes a bunch of electrical generators...all hooked into something on a table, under sheet, in the center of the room.
What is that?
Under this bedsheet is the product of ten years study, laborious hours spent over books and tinkering with electrical machines- Igor approaches the table and Victor rips off the sheet..

I present to you: Gordon! The...thing...called Gordon most closely resembles a chimpanzee, but a glance shows it to be something else entirely. You...you made this-
No. We made this. Igor’s eyes go over the creature, pinpointing all of his work; it’s all gone to this monstrosity. Victor primes machines, and they begin to hum and whir loudly.
The lungs, the spine, the heart, the brain, all your work. All impossible without you, as a matter of fact. Are you ready? Igor is clearly horrified; what has he been party to?
Victor, I don’t- What is this? You said this was about life, not death-

Stand back. Victor throws a massive switch, and there’s a sharp buzz electricity! We see arcs and loops of blue energy zap acr suspended cables, slamming into connectors on the bolts i Gordon's neck. Igor leaps back, startled. Steam rises off Gordon's body. The machines wind down. Victor approaches slowly.
...What-

Look. Listen. Igor looks and listens...and is amazed. Gordon is alive. Only marginally, but yes...the chest rises and falls. The eyes, horrible and monstrous, are open, and blinking. Igor’s shock and excitement is palpable. He runs his hand over its flesh and puts his ear to its chest, listening t the slow beating of the heart. He looks down at the animal; there’s an odd peace about i an innocence.
It’s...alive.
It’s alive.

It can’t quite move; the charge only lasts about an hour, and the body is mostly rudimentary mock up-
This is- Victor- you’ve created life from nothing, don’t you see how impor-
Tomorrow you shall accompany me to the college. I’ve announced that I will be making a presentation of my private studies-
I- to the college- as your assistant?
Assis- Igor, don’t be an idiot. You're my partner. Igor is completely overwhelmed.

The main building of the college is on a big, beautiful campus. Victor and Igor are unloading the big gurney off top of a coach, the bedsheet tied down tightly. Victor hands Igor down the heavy dynamo equipment, and Ig looks up at the college. It’s everything he’d ever dreame

Victor and Igor stand at the front of the big lecture hal The Gordon-Gurney and the dynamo are all set up. Victor i addressing the audience.  46. Igor is clearly uncomfortable, and concerned about his friend. Victor’s voice has a new element to it: a nervous tremor that we haven’t heard before.

Since the beginning of modern medicine, there has been an assumption regarding the nature of mortality, that being- that being that death is an unavoidable event whose inevitability should be taken for granted. I aim to show that life is not some heavenly grace given to us by an all-powerful god- but no- no instead that it is something natural-

Get on with it! We pan to reveal that the hall is nearly empty; of two hundred seats, only seven are filled. They all look disinterested and bored. In the back is Michael FINNEGAN, 21, dressed in only the finest clothes, refined, handsome and posh, a child of we with an accent so upper-crust he makes Victor and Igor so like they’re from Michigan. Ah- uh, yes- indeed, I will- Igor, start up the dynamo.
Yes, Master.
I present to you! I present to all of you here, the brave few who came-

(hurriedly) I built this homunculus out of parts primarily taken by from the London Zoo, which has had much difficulty in care of their exotic animals. I know your bloody type, Frankenstein, all sure of their theories and analysis, you listen, my wife Claudia, bless her soul, she trusted in that poppycock and what'd it get her, dead, said it was appendicitis well look how far it got her knowing the name, how much money we spent on the medicines, my daughter crying all night, all the treatments and she’s still dead isn’t she, she’s still dead because God was punishing me wasn’t he, for my folly, and her for parlay with the gypsies come up from White Chapel, and you think you're so smart, well you’re not so smart and I’m onto you and I’1l-

We'll see. We’ll see who’s so bloody smart. Turpin goes to leave, but stops for a moment, taking a ha look at Igor, who’s frozen in terror. Turpin shakes his head, mutters something, and storms out, Alistair followi
Well. That was exciting. The two of us both quite mad, shouting at each other. Stuff of legend.
Turpin rages out into the street, Alistair in tow.
I want a damn warrant, call me mad-
INSPECTOR, I can’t vouch for you, we saw no sign of any foul play and the shoes alone aren’t enough-
Did you see how they froze up when we mentioned the shoes, they’re hiding something-

And coupled with Victor's combativeness, his aggression...And the basement door, open, Straussman staring at it in fear the whole time. A warrant isn’t good enough, we need a raid. Will you back me if we go to Chief Inspector?

Listen, Alistair, I got excited in there but... (beat) I’m not mad. It comes out sounding more like a question than a stateme INT. VICTOR'S FLAT - VICTOR’S ROOM Victor is going through his closet, getting dressed, whil concerned Igor is nearby.
Did you have to needle him like that?

Enough. Victor pulls on his coat.

Listen, would you...come with me.
To the hearing?  78.
Yes. I intend to give them a piece of my mind and I'd rather- I'd rather not do it alone.
Victor, silent and meek, on a raised platform.

It’s beautiful but very sparse, Victor standing alone ina sea of negative space, with the board of directors across room from him behind a desk. His father sits nearby, star out a window. Igor stands off to the side, in a corner. DR. CLIVE, the head of the board, old and dignified, is reading from a list.

-students find Victor to be in turns rude, obnoxious, sinister, unpleasant, a loudmouth, a braggart, a false intellectual and a liar. D-...D- Doctor Clive, Doctor Cushing, Doctor Brannaugh, I j-

You leave him alone damn it!
Igor, don’t-

Has this reputable institution have no eye for real intelligence, real innovation, real revolution? Surely a real medical school would have this man performing his experiments in its hallowed halls, rather than in the dingy confines of a basement. Time will prove all of you fools, fools, and show this man to be a genius!
Victor looks to be in a state of shock. Igor’s flustered, breathing hard. The medical board exchange glances.
I’m sorry but...Who are you, exactly?

Victor and Igor sit in the coach as it rattles up the str Victor has his head pressed against the window, staring o Igor is clearly nervous he’s screwed up. Victor speaks without looking up, clearly lost in his own thoughts.

He wasn’t always like that you know. (beat) I had a brother. Henry. He was older than me by three years, but he never, he never bullied me the way the boys at schools were bullied by their brothers, he was...kind. He was intelligent, more than kind he was intelligent, my parents had such great hopes for him. One night, I went out in the snow, to watch a storm, I- I didn’t understand the danger, but Henry did. I found my way home, but they found Henry the next morning....not Dead yet, but, dying. My father rushed to town to get medicine, but by the time he got back it was too late. Henry had...died. Only moments before my father returned. He was fourteen. (beat) It changed my father. Broke him. He lost hope in everything, became...you’ve seen him. You've seen what he became. And I suppose it changed me, too. I could no longer, like so many do, live in fear of death, in fear of life, these mystical things. No. I had to see them made tangible. Henry deserved a second chance. My father deserved a second chance, everyone deserves a second chance. And now I’ve built something that can finally... Victor trails off, staring out the window.
What you did back in the college. No one has ever. No one has ever. I have only ever had one friend. I am happy that it is you. Igor nods. Then, after a hesitant beat...

Listen, Victor...I have faith in you. I have faith in your ideas, and I understand you think Finnegan is the only way to continue our work, but I ask you to reconsider. His motives are unclear, his lack of morality frightens me, and the fact that you’ve already given him most of your designs, our designs, scares me most of all. It’s all so dire now. All so dire.

Igor is nervously sketching out a design for a lightweigh collapsible wheelchair. He hears a sound from upstairs an waits, looking; it’s clear Victor has gone into his room not come out for some time. There’s a knock at the door.  81.

(whisper-yell) Victor! Victor! Nothing. No response. Igor tries to look out the window, and can’t see anything. Tension builds. He goes and picks up a fireplace poker, then moves slowly to the door; the knock comes again, startling him.

(one last try) Victor! No response. Igor swings open the door and sees- LORELEI! Igor yelps, dropping the poker behind the door, then trying clumsily to camoflage his spazz-out by straightening his hair. One of Baron Bomine’s carriages is parked in the street behind her.
(laughing) Did I scare you?
Yes, very much-

I thought since you were so bold in the morning, I should be bold tonight... (beat) Will you come with me to Baron Bomine’s Christmas ball? Igor looks hesitant; he glances back at Victor’s locked d at the top of the stairs, then at Lorelei, then back at t door, then Lorelei... INT. BARON BOMINE’S RESIDENCE - BANQUET ROOM Igor and Lorelei are at a long table, filled with rich an swanky looking high society types. Baron Bomine is seated nearby. A NOBLEMAN is talking animatedly his friends, Igo quietly listening and drinking.
Hospitals in general to me seem an indecent idea; piling the sick together like that, just seems against common logic. People go in with a broken leg, and come out dead from pneumonia.
S'not the hospitals.  82.
Beg pardon? Igor looks to Lorelei, horrified at having spoken up, but urges him on.

A good modern hospital should never have these problems. Mm. Probably quite right, I suppose; these days we seem to have wealth of medical students, and a dearth of real physicians. Are you a doctor?
I...I uh-
Yes, he was trained but never got a degree.
I say, are you looking for a job? I run a company up north; it would be a real boon to have someone on staff who knows a bit about medicine, especially a respectable man like yourself.
I...Uh, I would-
No need to give me an answer right away. I’11 look into it. What did you say your name was? Igor blanks out for a moment, shocked at the opportunity.

Igor. Igor smiles excitedly at Lorelei, who squeezes his hand. LATER...  83. Are you alright?

Yes, I just need a minute. INT. BARON BOMINE’S RESIDENCE - IGOR AND LORELEI’S ROOM A frustrated Igor wrestles off his jacket and shirt. He t on the back-brace, finally fully taking it off. He realiz with a start that he’s fine without it; he’s outgrown it. Pondering this, folds up the brace into a pocket-size bal and stares at, rolling it around in his hand. BOMINE CARRIAGE —- MORNING The carriage rumbles up the road, Igor happy in the backs clearly deep in thought. They turn onto Victor’s street, Igor looks up to see-

Go, go, up there. The carriage pulls around the corner, and Igor hops out, ducking immediately behind a fruit cart. Victor, we-
OPEN THIS DOOR, NOW! There’s no way out!
The bolt- get the bolt- Igor frantically bolts the door. There’s a crash upstairs the bobbies have breached the flat.
I've already sent one of Finnegan's men for a carriage-
Victor, stop, we have to get out of here!
And let them have my bloody machines, not likely! We can hear bobbies in the flat upstairs.  85.

Get a Lazarus fork. As Igor frantically searches for a fork, Victor turns, pulling up a panel from the floor, revealing a manhole co He begins using a wrench to unscrew the bolts on the cove Upstairs, the bobbies start pounding on the door, hitting with the battering ram. Igor finds a Lazarus Fork.

What’re you-

(barely conscious) F...Finnegan.

Frankenstein, Igor, what an unexpected surprise- my god what’re you covered in-
Sewage.
-delightful-

..-Ah. Why- why exactly did the police- you know on second thought, it doesn’t really matter. I suppose now you’1l have no choice but to leave London, post haste. At the very least, get your sewage covered bodies out of my father’s office.
Yes, very good. Finnegan snaps.

My family has an estate, the Castle Erskine, in Belgium. Quite rural and secluded, ideally suited to both your needs as a scientist and a, well- fugitive. We could set up a new lab, with help from Dettweiler, and-

Oh will you? Ha, right, I’1ll go prepare a coach. Finnegan heads out of the room. Victor sighs.

I’m not going ANYWHERE with you.
What? For the first time in our story, Igor is visibly ANGRY.
You amoral psychotic piece of shit- Scratch that, FURIOUS.
Igor-
How could you do that? To keep from me for months that you had killed a man and given me his name-
I didn’t kill him- you’re overreacting!
No, Victor, enough is enough-
You have a chance here to be part of-
Of what? Being lied to, chased by monsters and hunted by police-
Oh, don’t focus on the dark side-
NO! You’re- you’re a- a BAD FRIEND. Victor is startled by the simpleness of the accusation, a Maybe even hurt.
After all I did for you-
You care for no one but Victor Frankenstein-
I told you I didn’t kill Straussman-

Straussman was a waste of space, this fanfare from you is more of a funeral than his own family would've given him-
So he deserved to be toyed with like a puppet to help you escape, to have his eyes torn out of his head, where was HIS second chance-
I hadn't invented the fork yet, I couldn’t- Why are you saying these things, can’t you see- Finnegan reenters.  90.
All right, time is of the essence. Gentlemen, your coach is ready-
No Victor I see clearly. You are blind, and you have no capacity to see what’s happened, what you’ve done-
-also, if I could ask you to turn down the volume, my parents are home after all- Victor looks from Finnegan, to Igor and back.
You can go to your ruin. But I’m staying here.
Oh? And going where, exactly? Back to the Blue Meringue to resume your illustrious-—
It’s none of your concern.

None of my- Oh, just brilliant! What? To Lorelei? Where will you go? Igor is silent, staring at Victor; Victor can feel himsel being judged, slowly realizing that Igor is completely ou his control. His expression changes.

You fool. I created you. Clown! Circus freak! You think because I put you in a back-brace and cut your hair you can turn your back on me, go ahead, see how far you get in the real world with your “acrobat” and your new life! You stand in the way of the future, you're an embarrassment to everything I’d hoped to accomplish! Fine! Fine! I’m rid of you, rid of you, rid of you! Victor stands there, breathing hard, waiting for Igor to respond. He doesn’t. Victor fidgets, seeming about to spe again, then turns and storms out. Igor looks after him in shocked disappointment. MOMENTS LATER...  91. Igor stands on the balcony, watching Victor below as he g into a coach, stolid, emotionless. Finnegan appears next him, and looks down at the departing coach, then at Igor. He smiles.
So what’s next for you, then?

That’s sad to hear, old boy. Sad to hear. Seems you and Victor have had a bit of a falling out.
I said what I meant to say.
Very well, very well, good for you. (beat) You know, I knew Igor Straussman. Igor blinks. FINNEGAN (CONT’D) A real bore, nouveau riche, drug addict. Nothing like...this.
Ah-ah-ah. So who are you then? That’s the question. Doesn’t matter, really. Victor’s been very forthcoming with his designs, but I still need him for now. You, on the other hand-
Finnegan-

So let’s see: your benefactor has departed, your home has been ransacked by police, your identity revealed as a fraud...Do you understand what I’m saying? (beat) What I’m getting at, old sport, is that you won’t be missed. Igor is jabbed in the neck with a syringe, and one of Finnegan’s goons YANKS A BURLAP SACK OVER IGOR’S HEAD FRO BEHIND. A world where dead enemy soldiers are reassembled into new British troops. I see an unkillable army of your monsters, one million strong, marching across Paris, Moscow, Washington DC... Goodbye “Igor.” There’s the sound of a door opening.

A watery impact - SPLASH! Igor, the bag over his head, his ankles bound together an his hands tied behind his back, rapidly sinks down into t water. He struggles frantically, but can’t get free. A crucifix, dangling limply. There’s a scratching sound i the background. INT. SCOTLAND YARD - CHIEF INSPECTOR’S OFFICE Roderick Turpin sits alone in the police chief's officer the desk. Roderick-

...-Am I to understand-
